question:
A 74 year-old patient presents with progressive shortness of breath over the last years. He is a former
mining worker. CT shows calcified pleural plaques. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is considered a malignant course of the coronary arteries?
What are the differential diagnoses of a solid mass in the anterosuperior mediastinum?
reference_answer:
Thymoma, thyroid (mass), lymphoma, teratoma (and germ cell tumors), thoracic aorta
(e.g., aneurysm).

question: What are differential diagnoses of pulmonary cavities?
reference_answer:
Cancer, autoimmune diseases (granulomatosis with polyangiitis, rheumatoid arthritis),
vascular (bland/septic emboli), infection (e.g., tuberculosis), trauma (pneumatoceles), youth (CPAM, sequestration,
bronchogenic cyst); Cavity mnemonic.

question: Which MRI contrast agent can be used to detect an insufficiency of a biliary anastomosis?
What are possible distributions of pumonary nodules? Name one differential diagnosis for each distribution.
reference_answer:
Perilymphatic (e.g., sarcoidosis), centrilobular (special form: tree-in-bud; e.g.,
tuberculosis), diffuse (e.g., disseminated pulmonary metastasis).

question:
I am looking at a prostate MRI and see a lesion in the right posterolateral peripheral zone. The lesion is
hypointense in T2, hyperintense in DWI, hypointense in ADC and has a strong and early signal enhancement after
contrast administration. What kind of lesion could this be?

I am looking at an X-ray of the lumbar spine on a sagittal view. There are prominent endplate densities at
multiple contiguous vertebral levels, leading to a sclerotic-lucent-sclerotic appearance. The Patient has a history of
renal insufficiency. What is this appearance of the spine called and what is the most likely diagnosis?

I see a prominent pulmonary embolus in the right pulmonaly artery on a CT pulmonary angiography. What
are signs of right ventricular dysfunction?
reference_answer:
Abnormal position of the interventricular septum, contrast reflux into inferior vena
cava/liver veins, increased diameter of the right ventricle.

question:
A 24 year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever and jaundice. MRI of the liver shows
T1-hypointense, T2-hyperintense, segmental dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts, leading to a multicystic
appearance. There are multiple concrements in the intrahepatic bile ducts. The patient has no history of bowel disease.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
37

I am looking at an X-ray of the knee on a anteroposterior view of a patient after trauma. I see an elliptic bone
fragment projected parallel to the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau. What is the most likely diagnosis?
reference_answer: Segond fracture, indicative of a rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament.

question:
I see a right-sided enlarged lymph node posterolateral to the anterior belly of the digastric muscles on a CT
of the neck. What is the corresponding neck lymph node level?

I am looking at a CT angiography of the abdomen at the arterial phase. I see a complete defect of contrast
in the infrarenal aorta extending into both common iliac arteries. What is this condition called?

I see a lesion in an MRI of the liver that is hyperintense on T2 relative to the surrounding liver parenchyma,
but less than the intensity of water. Upon contrast administration, the lesion shows early peripheral nodular
enhancement that is shifting centripetally on delayed images. What is the most likely diagnosis?

What is the most commonly used chemotherapy agent in transcatheter arterial chemoembolisation of
hepatocellular carcinomas?

I see an adrenal lesion in an MRI of the epigastric region. The lesion demonstrates a strong signal dropout
on opposed-phase images. What is the most likely diagnosis?

I am looking at a contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen on the arterial phase in a patient with an infrarenal
abdominal aortic aneurysm that has been treated by EVAR. I see contrast agent in the aneurysmal sac, originating
from a left-sided lumbar artery. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Strongly hyperdense lesions are noted in the segmental pulmonary arteries of the right lower lobe on a noncontrast CT of the thorax. The patient has a history of vertebroplasty. What kind of lesions could that be?

I see a lesion in an MRI of the liver that is slightly hyperintense on T2 and hypointense on T1 relative to the
surrounding liver parenchyma. The lesion shows heterogenous arterial enhancement and a washout in the venous
phase. The lesion shows a central scar on T2w imaging. What is the most likely diagnosis?

I see prominent endplate densities at multiple contiguous vertebral levels on a sagittal X-ray of the spine
and a well-defined lesion of the sixth rib on a chest X-ray. What is the most likely underlying condition?

After application of contrast agent into a percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage, portal vein branches
distal to the biliary entry of the drainage show contrast enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?

I see densily sclerotic endplates in a sagittal X-ray of the spine of a 14 year old patient. What is the most
likely diagnosis?

I see mixed opacified and unopacified blood in the IVC at and cranial of the renal veins after on a abdominal
CT scan at an early contrast phase after i.v. contrast application. The infrarenal vena cava appears mostly unopacified.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
reference_answer: Contrast flow phenomenon in inferior vena cava (artifact).

question:
I see a synovial mass on a knee MRI. The mass is T1 and T2 hyperintense. There is a concomitant joint
effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
